work.p: Phrasing and imagery in this manuscript are reminiscent of phrases and ideas Whitman used in the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, ultimately titled "Song of Myself." Compare these lines from that edition: "I lean and loafe at my ease . . . . observing a spear of summer grass" and "Wherever the human heart beats with terrible throes out of its ribs" (1855, pp. 13, 36).

titleStmt.title: I entertain all the aches
a machine readable transcription

notesStmt.note: Because the manuscript has not been located it is difficult to speculate on the circumstances of its composition, but it is possible that it was written in the early 1850s as Whitman was preparing materials for the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The phrasing and imagery are reminiscent of passages in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, suggesting that this manuscript was composed before or early in 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: I entertain all the aches
bibl.orgName: The location of this manuscript is unknown.

lg.l: I entertain all the aches of the human heart
Outside the asteroids I reconnoitre at my ease.
